column3: Predictors of myopic macular degeneration in a 12-year longitudinal study of Singapore adults with myopia
column6: Predictors of myopic macular degeneration in a 12-year longitudinal study of Singapore adults with myopia
column7: Case-control study nested within population-based cohort studies; where cases refer to those who experienced PM onset or progression, while controls are those who did not experience PM onset/progression. This is NOT a retrospective cohort study because participants were NOT sampled on the basis of exposures (they were selected and compared on the basis of outcome, such that those with a specific outcome don't necessarily have the same level of exposure)
column10:
Inclusion: myopia at baseline (SER≤-0.50D); aged 40 years or older

Exclusion: missing MMD grading at baseline and/or at 12-year follow-up visit due to poor quality or absence of fundus photos; terminally ill (e.g., terminal cancer)
column11: population-based cohort studies (Singapore Malay Eye Study and Singapore Indian Eye Study) where study samples were representative of the general population in Singapore

From a list of names provided by the Ministry of Home Affairs, age-stratified random sampling was used

column23: In eyes with PM, an increase from META-PM category grade 2 or 3 at baseline to either grade 3 or 4 and/or expansion of existing chorioretinal atrophy, development of a plus lesion or enlargement of an existing plus lesion at 12-year follow-up. The area of the chorioretinal atrophy was assessed by ImageJ software.

column49: SiMES-1 study has a participation rate of 78.7% which is way higher than the moderate ROB cutoff of 67%, while SINDI study has a participation rate of 75.6%, also way higher than the cutoff.
column51: In the original cohorts (SiMES & SINDI) from which the study participants were sampled from, 6680 participated in the baseline examination, but only 859 remained after 12 years. Attrition rate is therefore 87.1% which is way higher than our high ROB (for follow-up>10y) cutoff of 40%. No information whatsoever on reasons for loss to follow-up, including number of deaths, etc, which precluded the calculation of participation rate among eligible (w.g. not due to death) participants. Therefore, we cannot rule out the possibility of potential bias to the observed relationship between investigated factors and outcomes.

column22: Staphyloma was not part of the definition. Fuchs spot was analysed as scar stage of mCNV. Definition of onset was no PM at baseline: no mCNV or LCs and myopic maculopathy at category 1 or lower, but developing PM at one of the follow-up visits.
column23: Staphyloma was not part of the definition. Fuchs spot was analysed as scar stage of mCNV. Qualitative comparison only.

column49: As the study sample was derived from clinical records at a secondary care clinic specific to high myopes, rather than from a population-based cohort study, participants in the study cannot be reasonably assumed to be reflect the characteristics of high myopes in the general population. A moderate risk of bias is given as opposed to high because the authors adequately addressed other potential sources of bias listed in this domain.
column51: N/A because this is a purely retrospective study that utilised past medical record
column53: Unclear if there were any missing data for RF or PF variables, but can be assumed to be minimal or absent because these factors are reasonably easy to collect and are considered fundamental in clinical practice: sex, baseline age and baseline AL.
column59: Authors used backward stepwise elimination method for model building, but they did not report the stopping criterion. However, given that the variables included in their final multivariable model are based on reasonable conceptual framework, there is a low risk that the reported results are spurious or biased.

column17: Subjective refraction wasperformed on all subjects whose visual acuity was worsethan 0.0 logMAR (Snellen 6/6 or 20/20) by trained and certified study optometrists. Autorefractor (KR8800; Topcon) eadings were used as the startingpoint, and refinement of sphere, cylinder, and axis was performed until the optimal visual acuity was obtained.
column18: (AL) was measured using a 10 MHz A/B-mode ultrasound device (Cine Scan)
column19: PM progression: 20 male eyes & 31 female eyes
column21: colour fundus photography; at baseline, 45° digital stereoscopic color retinal photographs of Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy  standard  field  1  (centred  on  the  optic  disc, stereoscopic) and standard field 2 (centred on the macula, non-stereoscopic) were taken for each eye by trained and certified photographers. One third of the fundus pictures were taken with a Topcon TRC-NW6S/7S (Top-con, www.global.topcon.com) camera (during the initial stages of the baseline study). The other two-thirds were taken  with  a  Canon  CRDGi  with  a  20D  SLR  back (Canon,  www.canon.com).  In  the  follow-up  study,  a Canon CR 2 with a 20D SLR back (Canon, www.canon.com) was used for all the participants.
column22:
PM was defined as category 2 or above, or any of the plus lesions. Specifically, myopic maculopathy was classified as being present when any of the following  features  was  identified:  diffuse chorioretinal atrophy, patchy chorioretinal atrophy, macular atrophy, lacquer cracks or myopic choroidal neovascularization (CNV) at the posterior pole. Because Fuchs spot is a pigmented spot representing the scarring phase of myopic CNV, we included Fuchs spot in the myopic CNV category. Notably, posterior staphyloma was not classified as indicative of myopic maculopathy. 

PM onset was defined as not having PM at baseline in either eye but PM in at least one eye at follow-up
column23:
defined as new signs of myopic maculopathy lesions, enlargement of the area of diffuse chorioretinal atrophy, patchy chorioretinal atrophy or macular atrophy, or an increase in the number of lacquer cracks in those who already had PM at baseline.

Using ImageJ version1.49u software, they measured the area of lesion(s) and of the optic disc. The size of a lesion was expressed as area of the lesion divided by the area of the optic disc. The change in lesion size was calculated as the ratio of the size of lesion at follow-up divided its size at baseline. Thus, a ratio larger than 1 was indicative of enlargement of the lesion
column24: Fundus photographs were graded by two graders (C.X.L,B.S.W) who had been trained for myopic maculopathy grading by a retinal specialist (K.O.M). The training involved three phases. Firstly, the two graders received instruction  on  grading  standard  fundus  photographs exhibiting myopic maculopathy from the specialist. Secondly, they underwent testing and further practice until they demonstrated excellent agreement with the specialist in grading myopic maculopathy (Weighted kappa values for all myopic maculopathy features were≥0.6). Finally,they were awarded certification

column3: Six-Year Changes in Myopic Macular Degeneration in Adults of the Singapore Epidemiology of Eye Diseases Study.
column6: Six-Year Changes in Myopic Macular Degeneration in Adults of the Singapore Epidemiology of Eye Diseases Study
column7: Case-control nested within 3 multi-ethnic population-based cohorts
column10:
Inclusion: myopia at baseline (SER≤-0.50D); aged 40 years or older; with FU data at 6-year visit

Exclusion: procedures that affected the native refractive state of the eye, such as a history of cataract surgery resulting in aphakia or pseudophakia, and/or self-reported refractive surgery in both eyes; missing refraction data in both eyes; combination of cataract surgery in one eye and missing refraction data in the other eye; missing or ungradable fundus photographs
column11: population-based cohort studies (Singapore Chinese Eye Study, Singapore Malay Eye Study and Singapore Indian Eye Study) where study samples were representative of the general population in Singapore
column12: recruitment officers sent letters of invitation, and conducted telephone calls and home visits to potential study participants. A person was considered “ineligible” to participate in the study if he/she had moved from the residing address, had not lived at the official address in the past six months, or was terminally ill (eg, cancer) or deceased. A person was deemed ‘not contactable’ after at least six unsuccessful telephone calls and six home visits. Participants who declined the initial invitation were re-contacted at later times, with at least one contact every six months. Apart from individualized communication with participants, we provided free transportation and pick-up services to participants who requested this, and used the media (television, local newspaper, community road shows) to publicize the study and increase participation.
column13:
For PM onset: 3373 eyes of 2009 px (eyes: 1681 Chinese, 731 Malays and 961 Indians)

column16: Whole group: 24.6±1.5mm (derived from worse eye, i.e. more severe MMD level or eye with higher myopia)
column17: Autorefraction was performed using an auto-refractometer (model RK5; Canon, Inc., Ltd., Tochigiken, Japan). Refraction was then subjectively refined by the study optometrists until the BCVA was obtained. The results from subjective refraction were used in the analysis. The spherical equivalent (SE) of the refractive error was defined as sphere plus half cylinder.
column18: Axial length (AL) was measured using noncontact partial coherence interferometry (IOL Master V3.01; Carl Zeiss Meditec AG, Jena, Germany).
column19:
PM onset: 1532 males and 1841 females

column20:
Baseline studies: from 2004 to 2011
- Singapore Malay Eye Study [2004–2006]
- Singapore Indian Eye Study [2007–2009]
- Singapore Chinese Eye Study [2009–2011]

- Singapore Malay Eye Study 2 [2010–2013]
- Singapore Indian Eye Study 2 [2013–2015]
- Singapore Chinese Eye Study 2 [2015–2017]
column21: After cycloplegia, color fundus photographs of Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study standard field 1 (centered on the optic disc) and Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study standard field 2 (centered on the fovea) were captured for each eye using standardized settings with a nonmydriatic retinal camera (Canon CR-DGi with 10D SLR back; Canon, Inc., Tokyo, Japan)
column22: PM was defined as category 2,3 or 4, or any plus lesion (LC, FS, mCNV). PM onset was defined as the development of PM at 6-year FU in eyes without PM at baseline.
column23: In eyes with PM, an increase from META-PM category grade 2 or 3 at baseline to either grade 3 or 4 and/or expansion of existing chorioretinal atrophy, development of a plus lesion or enlargement of an existing plus lesion at 6-year follow-up. The expansion of existing chorioretinal atrophy or plus lesion was defined by an enlargement of the area of chorioretinal atrophy or plus lesion by more than 50%. The area of the chorioretinal atrophy was assessed by ImageJ software.
column24: A detailed fundus photo-graph grading was performed by a single trained grader(W.Y.L.). The fundus photographs of both eyes were graded using a standardized protocol, and the grader was masked to the subjects’ characteristics. Adjudication was performed by retinal specialist (W.C.W.).  The kappa statistics showed high inter-grader agreement (diagnosis of Meta-PM categories were 0.94 [between W.C.W. and W.Y.L.])

column40: no missing data (for all variables included in multivariable model)
column41: no information; assumed to be complete case analysis
column42: Multivariable poisson regression (using backward stepwise method); correlation between two eyes was accounted for using generalised estimating equations (incorporated within the regression models)
column49: 75.6% participation rate at baseline which is higher than our moderate ROB cutoff of 67%. Furthermore, target population, etc. is well described and can be reliably assumed to be representative of the general population.
column51: Attrition rate after 6 years is 21.2% (78.8% of the 8584 remaining eligible participants at follow-up), which is quite close to being rated as having a low ROB. Detailed description and presentation of eligible participants vs eligible non-participants (at follow-up) are available (https://academic.oup.com/ije/article/50/1/41/6061452), and that the absolute differences between key characteristics like age (57.4 vs 57.3) & gender (female 52% vs female 50.9%) are small, the ROB is likely to be low.
column53: All prognostic factors included in the multivariable model are complete (no missing data); for risk factors (only baseline cataract has missing information, i.e. 68 eyes). Given that all key characteristics like age, baseline AL, sex, baseline SE are complete, ROB is likely to be low in this regard.
column59: backward stepwise method for multivariable model building.

column3: Five-Year Incidence of Myopic Maculopathy in a General Japanese Population: The Hisayama Study.
column6: Five-year incidence of myopic maculopathy in a general Japanese population: the Hisayama study
column7: Case-control study nested in a population-based cohort study called the Hisayama study
column10:
Inclusion: no PM at baseline, aged 40 years or older at baseline (criterion of the cohort study); attended follow-up examination 5 years after baseline; residents in the town of Hisayama
Exclusion: missing or upgradable fundus photos in both eyes;
column11: From existing population-based prospective cohort study called Hisayama study
column12: Residents were encouraged to paticipate in the health checkup
column13:
2164 patients (right eye analysed by default, but left eye analysed if only left eye developed PM at FU) —> of these 2164 participants, 27 eyes of 24 participants developed PM

PS: included participants are not exclusively myopic!
column14:
Whole group: 62.4 ± 10.9

Those who developed PM: 61.7 ± 11.2
column15: whole group (mean and SD pooled across sex):  -0.71 ± 1.75D
column16: whole group (mean and SD pooled across sex):  23.81 ± 1.4mm
column17: Objective refraction with AR-660 automatic refractometer (Nidek) after pupil dilatation with 1.0% tropicamide and 10%phenylephrine.
column19: whole group: 920 male participants and 1244 female participants
column21: colour fundus photography: 45-degree Topcon digital fundus camera (DRI-OCT Triton; Topcon Corporation); centred at the midpoint between temporal edge of optic disc and fovea in both eyes
column22: PM was defined as: category 2 or above, or any of the 3 plus lesions (mCNV, Fuchs spot, Lacquer cracks)
column24: All photographs were evaluated independently by 2 experienced ophthalmologists (E.U. and S.H.). When their judgments disagreed, the photographs were reexamined by 3 retinal specialists (E.U., S.H., and M.Y.), and the final judgment was determined after discussion. Graders were blinded to the clinical data of participants in the process of the photograph evaluation. The level of agreement between the graders was moderate (κ statistic: 0.86) to substantial for most features.
column27: assumed to have little variation from 5 years
column33: This study does not look at prognostic factors
column36: This study does not look at prognostic factors
column38: 4624 participants age≥40y/o in the town of Hisayama encouraged to partake in health checkup —> 2948 participants participated in eye exams —> 81 removed due to PM at baseline, 74 had missing or upgradable fundus photos in both eyes, 629 did not participate in FU —> 2164 remained
column41: Unclear; no info on missing data
column42: multivariable logistic regression with backward elimination procedure where variables with p<0.1 in univariable logistic regression was removed. SER not included in multivariable model due to multicollinearity (strong correlation with AL); only one eye per px included (RE by default unless LE was the only eye that developed PM)
column49: Targeted participants are representative of the older general population; there's also adequate description of baseline study sample, period of recruitment. Participation rate is 63.8% (2948 accepted invitation out of 4624 ) which is lower than 67% but greater than 50% so moderate risk of bias.
column51: Attrition rate is 21.2% (629 participants lost to follow-up out of 2948 participants who completed baseline examination) which is higher than the 20% cutoff rate for a follow-up period of <10y (moderate ROB); no information on reasons and no comparison between  completed and non-completed participants.
column57: No information on missing data but can be assumed to be minimal (if present) because variables included in the multivariable model are relatively easy to collect (age, sex and AL)
column59: No information on missing data but can be assumed to be minimal (if present) because variables included in the multivariable model are relatively easy to collect (age, sex and AL). In the multivariable regression model, variables are included based on a backward elimination procedure.

column3: Five-Year Cumulative Incidence and Progression of Myopic Maculopathy in a German Population.
column6: Five-year cumulative incidence and progression of myopic maculopathy in a German population
column7: Case-control nested within a population-based cohort study. Rationale: sampling was NOT based on exposures but outcomes (PM onset/progression or no PM onset/progression) so NOT a retrospective cohort study
column9: City of Mainz, Germany (presumed to be mostly German)
column10: Inclusion: Phakic eyes; spherical equivalent ≤-6D at baseline; gradable fundus photographs at baseline and follow-up
column11: Prospective population-based cohort study known as Gutenberg Health Study (GHS); conducted at the University Medical Center of the Johannes Gutenberg-University Mainz
column12: The study participants were selected randomly from local residents’ registration offices. According to German law, it is mandatory for each individual to register his/her personal and residential data within a week after moving to or from any location within Germany. Selected participants were contacted by letter and invited for the baseline examination. If they did not respond, then the recruitment team contacted them by phone. Persons, who were unable to come to the study center or did not want to participate, were asked to respond to some questions about demographics and their reasons for non-participation (non-responder questionnaire).
column13:
Whole group: 801 eyes of 519 participants.

PM onset: 494 eyes of 323 participants.

PM progression: 34 eyes of 27 subjects.
column14:
PM onset: 50.23 ± 9.17 (range probably 35 to 74).

PM progression: 56.70 ± 9.08 (range probably 35 to 74)
column16:
Baseline AL not reported. Hence AL at 5-y FU given below

PM onset: RE 26.42 ± 1.24; LE 26.52 ± 1.27.

PM progression: RE 28.44 ± 1.91; LE 28.40 ± 1.54.
column17: Objective refraction (not under cycloplegia); Humphrey Automated Refractor/Keratometer [HARK] 599; Carl Zeiss Meditec AG
column19:
Whole group: 174 male patients & 176 female patients

PM onset: 159 male patients & 164 female patients

PM progression: 15 male patients and 12 female patients
column21: colour fundus photography only; nonmydriatic fundus camera (Visucam PRO NM, Carl Zeiss AG) from both eyes with physiological pupils in a darkened room; the photographs relevant for the grading were 30-degree centred on the macula. In case of insufficient picture detail, photographs 45-degree centred on the optic nerve head were used
column22:
PM was defined as myopic maculopathy category 2 or above, or category 0/1 with plus lesions which include mCNV, Fuchs spot or lacquer crack) in BOTH eyes

PM onset was defined as no PM at baseline but presence of PM at 5-y FU.
column23:
Increase in stage of myopic maculopathy, enlargement(s) of existing lesion, or new lesion(s) at a different spot at the posterior pole.

PS: no mention of whether enlargement(s) was assessed qualitatively or quantitatively
column24: Graded at Mainz Ophthalmic Reading Centre. Graded by 2 masked graders following META-PM (grading on progression kappa=0.77). In case of divergent findings, a retinal specialist make the decision in a consensus meeting. Baseline and 5-year follow-up fundus photographs of an eye were aligned next to each other in a random and masked sequence to grade each eye.
column27: Not reported but can assume negligible variation from 5 years
column28:
Only 1 out of 323 participants developed PM over 5 years. Hence statistical analyses could not be performed!

column49:
Study population derived from a very large population-based cohort study with 15010 participants (Gutenberg Health Study) that are representative of the general population. However, initial participation rate (baseline) was 55.5% which is lower than the moderate ROB cutoff of 67% but higher than the high ROB cutoff of 50%.

Selection criteria for the study sample is appropriate (high myopia defined as SER worse than 6D and phakic).
column51:
Attrition rate was only 17.2% at the 5-year follow-up examination, which is lower than the moderate ROB cutoff of 20% for follow-up length <10y. Hence, low ROB although no information on reasons for lost to follow-up given, but this is this level of attrition is not likely to be an issue.

Furthermore, 102 participants out of 621 eligible participants were not included due to upgradable fundus images, but included and excluded participants did not differ in their characteristics.
column53: SER measured with auto refractor without cycloplegia: not an issue because participants were at least 35 years old. No information on missing data for prognostic factors but not likely to have any significant proportion of people with missing data as variables included in this study were relatively easy to collect, i.e. age, sex, SER (auto-refraction), AL and IOP.
